Manipulation of metal-support interaction holds great importance for the improvement of the catalytic performance. Herein, CeO2-x nano-islands decorated BN (CeO2-x-BN) porous material was engineered as an advanced carrier for Co3O4 catalyst. The optimal Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalyst shows excellent propane catalytic oxidation activity with propane reaction rate of 3.3 μmol·gCat. -1·s-1 at temperature of 219 °C, which is 13.2 times that of unsupported Co3O4.The remarkable catalytic performance could be due to the interfacial modulation of Co3O4 catalyst by the CeO2-x-BN support, which not only guaranteed a higher dispersion of Co3O4 but also promoted the oxygen vacancy generation and enhanced the active oxygen mobility. Meanwhile, the presence of electron transfer between cobalt oxide and cerium oxide (Co3++ Ce3+↔Co2++ Ce4+) increases the surface electron density of the catalyst, facilitating the adsorption and activation of reactants. This work exemplifies the importance of catalyst-support interactions for the upgradation of the metal oxides for high performance catalytic oxidation application. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4 Propane oxidation Nano-islands Oxygen vacancy Oxide-support interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are major air pollutants, exposing a serious threat to human health and the ecological environment [1,2]. Propane, as a typical VOC, constitutes a large portion in the harmful emissions from the energy involved industrial activities [3]. To address the stable CH bond in propane, catalyst aided combustion is commonly applied to achieve low-temperature propane combustion, which shows advantages of high efficiency and favorable feasibility [4]. Although the noble metal catalysts have been widely used in the practical tail-gas purification, research efforts have been continuously paid to the research on high-performance non-noble metal catalyst for the cost reduction and stability improvement [5–7]. Cobalt oxide typified transition metal oxides have been attracted particular research interest to serve as potential non-noble metal candidates, due to their outstanding characteristics such as variable oxidation states, abundant oxygen vacancies, adjustable surface and pore structure, low cost, wide availability, etc. [8,9]. To upgrade the reactivity of Co3O4 based catalyst and advance the replacement of noble metal catalyst, various tactics have been developed, such as size control [10,11], surface orchestrating [12], heteroatoms doping [13], pore texture modulation [14] and so on. For instance, Chen et al. discovered that surface hydroxyl groups functionalization of Co3O4 can alter the oxidation pathway of propane, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Ren et al. found that doping Ni into the Co3O4 spinel lattice can not only enhance the surface lattice oxygen mobility, but also promote CO2 desorption from the surface through the formation of unstable carbonates in propane oxidation [15]. We recently unlocked the efficacy of Cu doping [16], Ce, Al co-doping [17] and the anionic N doping [18] for the defects engineering of Co3O4 catalyst to induce the crystal distortions, promote the Co-O activation, enhance the creation of more active oxygen species, thereout boosting the catalytic oxidation of alkanes. To engender an enhanced active sites exposure, a favorable way is to construct supported Co3O4, which facilitates the dispersion of catalyst to benefit the reactant contact with the active sites [3]. Moreover, the interfacial electronic interaction between the catalyst and the support could induce the improvement of the intrinsic oxidation capability [19]. Metal oxide (MO), such as Al2O3, is commonly used as the catalyst support. For example, Cai et al. modulated Co/Al interactions in Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for propane oxidation reactions [20]. The Co-Al interaction resulted in the high dispersion of abundant active cobalt oxides with small particle sizes, which promised a higher oxidation ability. However, Al2O3 still suffers from drawbacks in the practical exothermic VOCs oxidation reaction. For instance, the low heat conductivity of Al2O3 leads to the hot spot, causing the catalyst sintering and pore collapse [21]. The surface acidity of Al2O3 could trigger side reactions, resulting in carbon deposition to block the active sites [22]. In addition, the hydrophilic surface of Al2O3 may induce the competitive adsorption of moisture with the reactant, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst [23]. 2D hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) with superiority of high specific surface area, hydrophobic surface, chemical stability, excellent heat conductivity etc. has recently gained extensive research interest in catalysis to serve as catalyst support [24]. Particularly, h-BN can maintain its structural integrity in high-temperature reaction environments, and its high thermal conductivity can effectively dispel the hot spot during the reaction to alleviate the sintering of the catalyst [25]. However, the interaction between BN and Co3O4 is comparably lower than that between metal oxide with Co3O4. It is thereout fascinating to bring the functions of metal oxide into BN to construct BN-MO composite as an advanced support for Co3O4 catalyst. CeO2 featuring with unique redox properties (Ce4+/Ce3+) could efficiently storage and release active oxygens, finding decent application in the oxidation reactions [26]. Meanwhile, CeO2 could exert a strong electronic interaction with the supported catalyst to improve the reactivity [27]. Therefore, it will be anticipated that the construction of cerium oxide functionalized BN carriers could live up to serve as advanced support for Co3O4 catalysts to be better applied in propane oxidation reaction. In this study, a simple solvothermal method was developed for the synthesis of CeO2-x-BN, with CeO2-x present as nano-islands on the surface of BN. When used as support, it facilitated a uniform dispersion of Co3O4 even at a high loading. Meanwhile, an enhanced electronic interfacial interaction is evidenced, which profoundly boost the oxidation activity of Co3O4 catalyst. This study offers an insight for the support engineering to boost the catalytic performance of Co3O4 catalysts for propane oxidation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Boric acid (99 %, Macklin), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (99 %, Macklin), melamine (Sinopharm), ammonium bicarbonate (99 %, Sinopharm), and cerium nitrate hexahydrate (99 %, Macklin) were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of CeO2-x-BN and BN carriers Boric acid, melamine and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in deionized (DI) water and then the mixed solution was stirred in an oil bath at 110 °C until the solvent was completely evaporated. Subsequently, the precursor powder was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 24 h and then calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h to obtain the final CeO2-x-BN. BN was prepared with similar procedure but without adding of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O. 2.2.2 Preparation of supported Co3O4 catalysts The supported Co3O4 catalysts were prepared by a precipitation method. Specifically, 0.2 g of CeO2-x-BN was firstly dispersed in anhydrous ethanol under sonication for 10 mins. Then, 0.593 g of CoCl2·6H2O was added under stirring at 30 °C for 6 h. Subsequently, 0.593 g of NH4HCO3 dissolved in 5 mL of DI water was added into the above mixture. The precipitate was washed and dried at 60 °C in an oven overnight, which was calcined at 400 °C in a muffle furnace for 4 h. The obtained powder was washed with DI water at 80 °C and dried at 60 °C overnight to obtain the final Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalyst. As references, Co3O4/BN was prepared with the similar procedure but using BN as the support and Co3O4 was synthesized without adding any support. 2.3 Catalytic characterizations All of the prepared catalysts were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), internet content provider (ICP), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and Raman spectroscopy. The reaction mechanism of the propane oxidation was investigated by the in situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) technique. The experimental details and instruments information are summarized in the Supplementary Information. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation Propane oxidation was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor using reactant gas containing of 0.5 vol. % C3H8 and 20 vol. % O2, balanced with Ar. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was set at 60,000 mL·g-1·h-1 with reaction temperature increased from room temperature to 300 °C (2 °C·min-1). The products were in-situ tested by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014). C3H8 conversion was acquired from the following formula: C 3 H 8 conversion ( % ) = [ C 3 H 8 ] i n − [ C 3 H 8 ] o u t [ C 3 H 8 ] i n × 100 ( % ) wherein, [C3H8] in and [C3H8] out represent the inlet and outlet C3H8 concentrations, respectively. To obtain the information of apparent activation energy (Ea), the reaction was controlled at the kinetic regime (with C3H8 conversion below 15 %). The equation below was used for the calculation of Ea by acquiring the slope: lnk = − Ea RT + C where k is the reaction rate, T stands for the absolute temperature, and R represents the molar gas constant. 3 Results and discussions The morphology of CeO2-x-BN and BN was first investigated by SEM characterization. It can be seen from Fig. S1 that the prepared BN (Fig. S1a-b) and CeO2-x-BN (Fig. S1c-d) samples exhibit nano-plate morphology with plenty of edges, which will provide enhanced exposed surface, benefiting the catalyst loading and dispersion. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the TEM image of CeO2-x-BN catalyst shows that cerium oxide is uniformly dispersed on the surface of BN. The HR-TEM image of Fig. 1b clearly shows crystal with lattice spacings of 0.33 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of CeO2-x domains. Meanwhile, BN substrate with lattice spacing of 0.36 nm is also detected. The EDS elemental mapping demonstrates a uniform distribution B, N and Ce elements for CeO2-x-BN, indicating that Ce species are evenly dispersed on BN skeleton (Fig. 1c-f). This indicates the successful synthesis of BN confined CeO2-x islands. ICP results indicate that Ce elemental content on the BN carrier was 0.9 wt. % (Table S1). XRD analysis (Fig. 2 a) shows diffraction peaks at 26.8°, 42.6°, and 76.8°, corresponding to the (002), (100), and (110) crystal planes of BN (JCPDS No. 34–0421), respectively for the sample of CeO2-x-BN and BN. The absence of the crystal peaks for CeO2-x can be attributed to the low content and small size of CeO2-x dispersed on the surface of BN [28]. Fig. 2b shows the Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 XPS spectra of CeO2-x-BN, which can be deconvoluted into five 3d5/2 peaks denoted as v0 (881.7 eV), v (882.9 eV), v′ (885.7 eV), v″ (889.0 eV), and v‴ (897.6 eV), and the other five 3d3/2 peaks including u0 (899.1 eV), u (901.2 eV), u′ (903.0 eV), u″ (907.7 eV), u″ (907.7 eV) and u‴ (916.8 eV), respectively [29]. The peaks denoted as v0, v′, u0, and u′ are attributed to Ce3+, whereas the peaks marked as v, v″, v‴, u, u″, and u‴ are assigned to Ce4+. It is obvious from the results in Fig. 2b that Ce in CeO2-x-BN is mainly existed as Ce3+. Ce L3-edge XANES profile further confirms that Ce is present in the form of Ce3+, which is different to that of CeO2 while similar to the peak of CePO4 (Fig. 2c) [30]. Using BN and CeO2-x-BN as carriers, Co3O4 nanoparticles could be well dispersed, as evidenced by the TEM characterizations in Fig. S2 and Fig. 3 a. The average particle sizes of Co3O4 are 11.8 nm and 10.2 nm on BN and CeO2-x-BN carriers, respectively. As comparison, pure Co3O4 sample is obviously agglomerated with a particle size of about 18.6 nm (Fig. S2a-b). The Co3O4/Ce2O3-BN sample has the smallest size of cobalt oxide nanoparticles, which can increase the exposure of the defective surface of the oxide with the decrease of particle size [31]. At the same time, the (311) crystalline facet of Co3O4 and (111) crystalline facet of CeO2-x are also identified on the Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalysts (Fig. 3b). The loading amount of Co3O4 is 44.4 % as tested by the ICP characterization (Table S2). From Fig. 3c-h and Fig. S3, it can be observed that Co elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of CeO2-x-BN and BN supports, which further proves the uniform dispersion of Co3O4. XRD patterns in Fig. 4 a illustrates the characteristic peaks at 2θ of 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 55.6°, 59.4°, and 65.2° in line with the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) crystal planes of the spinel phase Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 74–2120), respectively [32,33]. The wider half peak width of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN compared to Co3O4/BN further proves that the presence of CeO2-x on the surface of BN helps the dispersion of Co3O4. From the N2 adsorption isotherm, it could be seen that all catalysts show typical IV isotherms, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure (Fig. 4b). Meanwhile, the pore size distribution of the catalysts was further calculated by using NL-DFT method. Compared to Co3O4 and Co3O4/BN, Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN has larger pore sizes mainly concentrated at 0.7–2.7 nm (Fig. 4c). As listed in Table 1 , the specific surface area of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN (154.8 m2·g-1) and Co3O4/BN (112.4 m2·g-1) is significantly larger than that of Co3O4 (42.1 m2·g-1), which means the porous structure of CeO2-x-BN and BN supports provides a larger specific surface area, thus facilitating the dispersion of Co3O4. Meanwhile, the presence of CeO2-x nano-islands exert strong interaction with Co3O4, which could anchor the Co3O4 to prevent the catalyst agglomeration and help tune the electronic structure of Co3O4 to boost the intrinsic oxidation ability. As the XPS result shown in Fig. 4d, the Co 2p XPS spectra could be deconvoluted into peaks at 781.0 and 796.0 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively [13]. It can be seen from Table 1 that the proportion of Co2+/Co3+ follows Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN > Co3O4/BN > Co3O4. The presence of redox Ce3+/Ce4+ on the surface of BN induce the electron transfer to Co3O4, leading to the rise of Co2+ percentage. At the same time, the enhancement of the electron density on the catalyst surface will facilitate the adsorption and activation of the reacting molecules, which in turn may favor the catalytic reaction. The O 1 s XPS spectra could be deconvolved into two peaks at around 530.0 and 531.0 eV, which corresponds to the lattice oxygen (Olatt) and surface oxygen (Osurf) of the catalysts (Fig. 4e) [34]. It is generally believed that Osurf formed in the oxygen vacancy (Ov) could participate in the oxidation reaction following a Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism, which plays a key role for the improvement of the oxidation activity. From Table 1, it can be seen that the ratio of Osurf/Olatt follows Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN > Co3O4/BN > Co3O4. This indicates that Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN has the highest percentage of surface oxygen, proving that the presence of cerium oxide enhances the adsorption of active oxygen on the surface of the catalyst. Moreover, EPR characterization demonstrates that Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN exhibits a higher concentration of oxygen vacancy defects, which may promote the implanting of active oxygen species (Fig. 4f), thereby enhancing the catalytic oxidation reaction. The Raman spectrum of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN in Fig. 5 a shows five characteristic peaks at 191, 465, 514, 612 and 678 cm-1, corresponding to the F2g 1, Eg, F2g 2, F2g 3 and A1g structure vibrations of spinel Co3O4, where A1g is associated with crystal vibrations at the octahedral sites and F2g 1 corresponds to the crystal vibrations of tetrahedral sites [35]. It can be found that the A1g peaks of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalysts shifts to lower value and the half-peak widths become broader, which is induced by the lattice distortion of the Co3O4 spinel structure by confining by CeO2-x-BN support [36]. H2-TPR experiments were performed to evaluate the redox property and oxygen mobility. As shown in Fig. 5b, two reduction peaks, corresponding to the reduction of Co3+→Co2+ at low temperature and Co2+→Co0 at high temperature, respectively are observed [37]. It is obvious from Fig. 5b that the reduction peak of the supported Co3O4 catalysts shifts to lower temperature as a whole. The low-temperature reduction peak is commonly used to reflects the reactivity of the surface lattice oxygen [38]. Compared with the reduction temperature of pure Co3O4 (364.5 °C), the reduction temperature of the Co3O4/BN was significantly reduced to be 318.7 °C. This indicates that there is a strong oxides-support interaction to promote the redox properties. Moreover, Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN has a further lowered reduction temperature (316.7 °C), suggesting the activation of Co-O over to CeO2-x-BN facilitate the mobility of surface O. Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN, Co3O4/BN and Co3O4 catalysts were tested for catalytic performance of propane oxidation using a fixed-bed reactor. The results of propane oxidation exhibit that the catalytic performances of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN are significantly better than those of Co3O4 loaded on BN supports (T50 = 217 °C, T90 = 229 °C) and pure Co3O4 catalysts (T50 = 240 °C, T90 = 254 °C) (Fig. 5c). Moreover, the propane conversion rate based on the mass of Co3O4 has been calculated at the reaction temperature of 217 °C. Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN displayed a propane conversion rate of 6.7 μmol g(Co3O4)-1 S-1, which is 1.9 and 33.5 times that of Co3O4/BN and pure Co3O4, respectively. By comparing the performance of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN with the reported literatures, it can be found that Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN is among one of the most significantly active catalysts for propane oxidation (Table S3). In order to identify the intrinsic activity of the catalysts, the activation energy (Ea) was evaluated in the Arrhenius plot illustrated in Fig. 5d. The Ea value of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN (102.9 KJ·mol-1) is significantly lower than that of Co3O4/BN (118.2 KJ·mol-1) and Co3O4 (140.8 KJ·mol-1) catalysts, which proves that the Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN has the best intrinsic oxidation ability for propane oxidation. Temperature-resolved in situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectra (in situ DRIFTS) of the catalysts were carried out to analyze the catalytic reaction process of propane oxidation. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the vibrational peaks observed at 2850–3020 cm-1 and 1357 cm-1 are attributed to vas (CH3), vas (CH2), vs (CH3), and δs (CH3), respectively, suggesting the characteristic peaks of adsorbed gas-phase propane [39]. Moreover, the peaks at 1724 cm-1 can be attributed to the vibrational vibrations [40] of vs (C=O). The peak at 1548 cm-1 and 1426 cm-1 can be attributed to vibrations of vs (COO) and the peak at 1255 cm-1 belongs to the vibrations of vs (CH3COO) [41]. Besides, the vibrational peak near 1203 cm-1 can be assigned to vs (CO-C) [42], and the peak at 1030 cm-1 is attributed to v (CO3 2-) [43]. For the sample of Co3O4/BN and Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN (Fig. 6b-c), vibrational peaks associated with vs(C=C) and δs (CH) are observed near 1610 cm-1 and 1432 cm-1, suggesting that propane is dehydrogenated rapidly to produce propylene after adsorption on the catalyst surface [44]. This proves that the strong oxides-support interaction boosts the critical step of propane dehydrogenation [45]. It has been reported in the literature that the olefinic pathway significantly reduces the energy barrier for the catalytic combustion reaction of propane, thereby increasing the catalytic efficiency [46]. The reaction intermediates are mainly carboxylates and carbonates, and these intermediates accumulate in large quantities and cannot continue to be converted further over pure Co3O4. However, lower olefins peaks appear on the surface of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN, indicating a faster conversion of the olefin intermediates compared to that of Co3O4/ BN. As discussed above, a possible reaction pathway for the total oxidation of propane over Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalyst is depicted in Fig. 6d Specifically, propane is firstly adsorbed and then interacts with the active sites to form the H3CC(OH)HCH3 species, which is further dehydrated to form the H2C C(O)CH3 species and oxidized in the presence of a continuous supply of oxygen to H2CCOOCH3. Subsequently it continues to be oxidized to (O)COOCH3 with the simultaneous production of CO2 and H2O. The above results sufficiently highlight the improved intrinsic oxidation ability of Co3O4 catalyst by the interaction with CeO2-x-BN, which facilitate an enhanced kinetic oxidation process. Based on the above characterization, it could be summarized that the excellent performance of Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN could be attributed to: (1) the porous BN provides a high specific surface area and porous substrate, which could enhance the adsorption of reactive molecules. (2) the incorporation of the CeO2-x on the surface of BN support can facilitate the dispersion of Co3O4 nano-particles. (3) The synergistic interaction between CeO2-x and cobalt oxides enables the transfer of electrons from Ce to Co3O4, which could boost the oxidation ability to promote the intermediates transformation. 4 Conclusion In this work, the CeO2-x-BN composite was orchestrated as the support for the Co3O4 catalyst. The porous BN provides a larger specific surface area and abundant pore structure. Meanwhile, the introduced CeO2-x nano-islands effectively functionalize the surface of BN to engender an enhanced interaction with the supported Co3O4. Correspondingly, Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN guaranteed a high dispersion of Co3O4 catalysts with distorted lattice, enhanced oxygen vacancies and facilitated oxygen mobility. Moreover, the interaction between CeO2-x-BN and Co3O4 builds an electronic rich Co3O4, which facilitates the adsorption and activation of reactants. This study provides a new insight into the design of high-performance Co3O4 catalysts via engineering an advanced support. coredata.dc:description: Manipulation of metal-support interaction holds great importance for the improvement of the catalytic performance. Herein, CeO2-x nano-islands decorated BN (CeO2-x-BN) porous material was engineered as an advanced carrier for Co3O4 catalyst. The optimal Co3O4/CeO2-x-BN catalyst shows excellent propane catalytic oxidation activity with propane reaction rate of 3.3 μmol·gCat. -1·s-1 at temperature of 219 °C, which is 13.2 times that of unsupported Co3O4.The remarkable catalytic performance could be due to the interfacial modulation of Co3O4 catalyst by the CeO2-x-BN support, which not only guaranteed a higher dispersion of Co3O4 but also promoted the oxygen vacancy generation and enhanced the active oxygen mobility. Meanwhile, the presence of electron transfer between cobalt oxide and cerium oxide (Co3++ Ce3+↔Co2++ Ce4+) increases the surface electron density of the catalyst, facilitating the adsorption and activation of reactants. This work exemplifies the importance of catalyst-support interactions for the upgradation of the metal oxides for high performance catalytic oxidation application.
